Rovey — 2
The other democratic parties — the Social Democrats* Liberals
and Republicans — no longer share the responsibilities of Governing * as
all of them once did in the De Gasperi governments. And if the Christian
Democrats are in a period of transition, these “lay" democratic parties,
as the Italians call them, are in periods of genuine crisis. To be blunt
about it, they ar©facing the possibility of political extinction.
Their showings in the June elections were bad enough. The next
election might wipe them out.
This would surely be an unfortunate development for the Italian
democracy, as many Christian Democrats would agree. These three parties are
needed. They contain some of the most intelligent and devoted men in Italian
public life, whether in or out of the government, these parties exert an
influence on the Christian Democrats of a kind that neither the totalitarian
left nor right is capable of exerting. They help the majority of Christian
Democrats keep their sometimes unwleldly party in the middle of the road.
And they provide a democratic alternative to the Christian Democracy for
Italians unwilling to vote for a Catholic party.
And so more than Just those who vote for the Social Democrats,
Liberals and Republicans are watching with concern the efforts of these
parties to clarify their positions and firm up their ranks. I think these
efforts should be of interest to Americans, who, after all, have a rather
large stake in what happens to the Italian democracy. And so I thought I
would devote this Letter from It§|y to a brief review of the current posi¬
tions of these three democratic parties and their efforts to improve those
positions.
First of all, here is what happened to these parties in the
elections of last June*
The Social Democrats, largest of the three, dropped 600,000 votes
from their 1948 total. They polled a million, 200 thousand, and their
representation In the Chamber of Deputies went down from 33 to 19.
The Liberals, who had polled just over a million votes in 1948,
dropped to 800,000, and won only 14 Chamber seats compared with 19 in the
previous parliament.
The Republicans polled only 439*000 votes and dropped from nine
Chamber seats to five.
One of two questions generally comes to the mind of a foreigner
examining these unhappy election results. The first one is, why don't these
parties combine forces for added strength? And the second question isi why
don't these parties throw their combined support to Premier Pella and parti¬
cipate in his government, if they are eager to keep the Christian Democrats
in the middle of the road?
The answer is that both of these courses have been considered,
and, up to now, rejected, for reasons having to do with the election vaults
and the differing characters and different problems of the parties involved.
Let1b take up that second question first* why don’t these three
parties support Pella? Together they have 38 votes. If they withhold these
38 votes, Pella has no alternative to accepting the 40 Chamber votes of the
Monarchists and paying a price for their support.
